intro: Schistostephium rogersii, commonly known as Rogers' mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant belonging to the Loranthaceae family. It grows on the branches of various host trees, primarily in arid and semi-arid regions of the southwestern United States. The plant has small, scale-like leaves and produces yellowish-white flowers that are often clustered in dense inflorescences. Its berries are typically red or orange, containing seeds that are dispersed by birds. Schistostephium rogersii plays a unique ecological role by relying on host trees for nutrients while also providing food for wildlife.
